column1: Throughout the third great geological Time--the Mesozoic--these rivers grew in importance
column2: and the lowest portions of the Missouri began to form a tributary of some size. Still the Ohio had not united with the Mississippi
column3: and both of these rivers emptied into an arm of the Mexican Gulf
column4: which then reached to a short distance above what is now their junction.In point of time
column5: the Ohio is probably older than the Mississippi
column6: but the latter river grew and eventually absorbed the Ohio as a tributary.In the early part of the fourth great geological Time--the Cenozoic--nearly the whole continent was above water. Still the Gulf of Mexico covered a considerable portion of the extreme Southern States
column7: and one of its bays extended as far north as the mouth of the Ohio
column8: which had not yet become a tributary of the Mississippi. The Missouri throughout its entire length was at this time a flowing river.
